questions.question: If a company is a big pizza üçï, what is a 'stock'?
options: The whole pizza
A tiny slice of the pizza
The pizza box
The delivery driver
questions.feedback: A stock is like owning a small slice of the company. The more slices you have, the more of the company you own.

questions.question: Why would a company sell stocks?
options: Because they have too much money
To give away free products
To get money to grow bigger and create new things
To have a big party
questions.feedback: Companies sell stocks to raise money for exciting projects, like building a new factory or inventing a cool new toy.

questions.question: What does 'diversification' mean? ü§î
options: Putting all your money in your favorite company
Hiding your money under your bed
Only buying stocks on a Tuesday
Spreading your money across many different stocks
questions.feedback: It's the idea of 'not putting all your eggs in one basket.' Diversifying is a smart way to lower your risk.

questions.question: A news report says 'RoboCorp's new jetpack is a huge success!'. What will likely happen to its stock price? üìà
options: It will go down
It will stay the same
It will go up
It will disappear
questions.feedback: Good news and popular products usually make more people want to buy a stock, which drives the price up.

questions.question: What is a 'portfolio'?
options: A type of suitcase
A fancy photo album
A collection of all the different stocks you own
The name of a company
questions.feedback: Your portfolio is your personal collection of investments, like a treasure chest for all your stocks.

questions.question: What is a 'ticker symbol'?
options: A secret code to unlock a game
A short nickname for a stock on the market (like AAPL for Apple)
A sticker you get for buying a stock
A button that makes a ticking sound
questions.feedback: Ticker symbols are short and easy-to-type nicknames for companies on the stock market.

questions.question: What is a 'Bull Market' üêÇ?
options: A market that sells bulls
A time when most stock prices are going DOWN
A time when most stock prices are going UP
A very slow market
questions.feedback: A bull market is when the market is strong and prices are generally rising. Think of a bull charging forward!

questions.question: And what about a 'Bear Market' üêª?
options: A market where you can buy teddy bears
A time when most stock prices are going DOWN
A time when most stock prices are going UP
A very fast market
questions.feedback: A bear market is when the market is weak and prices are generally falling. Think of a bear hibernating.

questions.question: What is a 'dividend'?
options: A math problem
A penalty for losing money
A small bonus payment from a company to its shareholders
A type of vegetable
questions.feedback: Some companies share their profits with shareholders by giving them a dividend, which is like a small cash reward for being an owner.

questions.question: What's the #1 rule of investing?
options: Only buy stocks with cool names
Never sell a stock
Don't be afraid to lose, but aim to learn!
Buy what your friends buy
questions.feedback: The goal is to learn how the market works. Every decision, win or lose, is a learning opportunity. Great job!
